title: My Child Often Makes Simple Mistakes in Math – Why?
description: Understanding careless errors and how to reduce them without creating anxiety.

content.intro: "They know how to do it but keep making silly mistakes!" This is one of the most frustrating parent experiences. Here's what's really happening.

sections.text: Kids don't usually make mistakes because they don't care. They make mistakes because:

items: **Processing overload:** Working memory is maxed out
**Automaticity gaps:** Some facts aren't automatic yet
**Fatigue:** Attention fades late in a session

sections.text: Checking work, catching errors, self-monitoring – these are executive function skills. Kids' brains are still developing these abilities.

rows: Not reading carefully or operation isn't automatic

sections.text: Many "careless" errors disappear when facts are fully automatic. More practice on basics = fewer errors later.
Speed isn't the goal for struggling kids. "Take your time" actually helps.
Teach specific checking strategies: Does this answer make sense? Can I estimate to verify? What operation did I use?
Fewer problems done well > many problems done carelessly. Quality over quantity.

items: Work on graph paper for alignment

sections.text: Don't say "be more careful" – it doesn't help. Instead, give specific strategies: "Point to each number as you read it."

items: Problems that don't improve with practice

faq.question: Should I point out every mistake?
faq.answer: No. It becomes demoralizing. Focus on patterns. Address the types of errors, not every instance.

faq.question: Will errors go away with age?
faq.answer: Some will (executive function develops). Others need targeted intervention. Practice helps regardless.

faq.question: Is this a sign of a learning disability?
faq.answer: Not necessarily. Most "careless" errors are developmental and improve with practice and age. Persistent issues despite practice may warrant evaluation.

cta.text: SoroKid's repetitive practice builds the automaticity that reduces careless errors.
